Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the cost of implementing the Common Core standards in Florida by stating that there is no additional cost.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it contradicts the information provided by various sources, including the Florida Stop Common Core Coalition and the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there is no additional cost with the implementation of the Common Core standards in Florida, which is contradicted by the evidence provided.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores alternative explanations provided by experts and analysts who argue that the implementation of Common Core carries expenses.
Understate: The claim understates the actual cost of implementing Common Core in Florida, as evidenced by the $100 million in Common Core projects detailed by the Florida Department of Education.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not considering the challenges and difficulties in keeping costs flat during the implementation of Common Core, as mentioned by education analyst Anne Hyslop.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there are additional costs associated with the implementation of the Common Core standards, as stated by various sources and experts.
